info.game_comments:
Brian Weikle game 1.

(Judge Hatchett: I'll talk about the law later.  Right now Jeopardy! is in session!)

(1, 1).clue: Composer Edvard Grieg was born in this Norwegian city that makes us think of actress Candice

(2, 1).clue: In the 1970s this Great Lakes state cut down on litter with the nation's first  10-cent bottle refund law

(3, 1).clue: Superman could tell you this odorless, colorless gas bears atomic no. 36

(5, 1).clue: Most candy is made by crystallizing this

(6, 1).clue: He sought the Republican presidential nomination in 2000

(1, 2).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew reports from London.)  Tower Bridge was built in this century at a cost of over a million pounds; average annual income was 40 pounds

(2, 2).clue: Classy car dealers like Beverly Hills Mercedes-Benz use this synonym for "used"

(3, 2).clue: First isolated by Sir William Ramsay & Morris Travers, this gas takes its name from the Greek word meaning "new"

(5, 2).clue: This drink has been traced back to the Ethiopian province of Keffa or Kaffa (maybe the source of its name, too)

(6, 2).clue: On this show, Jack Klugman starred as a crime-solving forensic investigator

(1, 3).clue: The annual tomato battle, or Tomatina, held in Bunol in this country really does paint the town red

(2, 3).clue: If you find an original zoot suit in a secondhand store, it's probably from this decade

(3, 3).clue: This gas is released during photosynthesis

(5, 3).clue: Pindar tells of one of these races in which 40 teams were entered and only one finished

(6, 3).clue: It's the geographic entity outlined here

(1, 4).clue: We have a "hunch" you can visit this author's home at No. 6 Place des Vosges in Paris

(2, 4).clue: In "I am a Fugitive from a Chain Gang", a war veteran tries to sell this but the pawnbroker has too many already

(3, 4).clue: When bubbles of this gas form in a scuba diver's blood, the bends can occur

(4, 4).clue: "Here's another nice mess you've gotten us into"

(5, 4).clue: This daily chronicler of the fashion industry launched "W", a bi-weekly, in 1972

(1, 5).clue: Legend says this capital is named for Kii, one of the 3 brothers who founded it

(2, 5).clue: Fancier term for dealers in used books, the first A in their association, the ABAA

(3, 5).clue: In the "heavy water" used in nuclear physics, deuterium replaces the usual form of this gas

(5, 5).clue: Western state whose 2-letter postal abbreviation sounds like a deadly sin

(1, 1).clue: A sculpture by this artist of the American West is seen here

(2, 1).clue: (Here is the judge. She'll be giving us all the clues in this category.) In law libel is written defamation; this is oral

(3, 1).clue: This tree grows slowly & usually doesn't produce acorns until it is about 20 years old

(5, 1).clue: The Ruckers family of Antwerp in this present country were sort of the Stradivariuses of the harpsichord

(6, 1).clue: Jerry Lewis' partner who occupied the White House from 1837 to 1841

(1, 2).clue: This portrait painter was the first president of the Royal Academy of Arts

(2, 2).clue: (Hatchett reads the clue.) This certificate is a mandate of the court & comes in "bench" & "search" types

(3, 2).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew reports from the Science Museum of Minnesota.) The Douglas fir, one of whose enormous trunks is seen here, belongs to this cone-bearing order of trees.

(5, 2).clue: The strings of a harpsichord produce sound this way, not by being struck like a piano's

(6, 2).clue: Charlie Brown's tomboy friend kidnapped by the SLA in 1974

(1, 3).clue: The 27-panel fresco "Detroit Industry" in the Detroit institute of Arts is by this noted muralist

(2, 3).clue: (Hatchett reads the clue.)  It's the questioning of a witness by the party opposed to the one that produced the witness

(3, 3).clue: The blue gum, which has been introduced into the U.S., & the Sydney peppermint are species of this tree

(5, 3).clue: This term was often synonymous with a harpsichord, as in Bach's "Well-Tempered" one

(6, 3).clue: "Hot Stuff" singer whose medal events include the pentathlon & rhythmic gymnastics

(1, 4).clue: Large canvases of 2 or 3 fuzzy-edged rectangles of color were the hallmark of this abstract painter who died in 1970

(2, 4).clue: (Hatchett reads the clue.) If accepted, the "circumstances" can lower a degree of homicide to just manslaughter

(3, 4).clue: The raffie variety of this tropical tree produces leaves that grow to more than 65 feet in length

(5, 4).clue: The harpsichord's clean sound made it useful for this technique of playing multiple melodies at once

(6, 4).clue: Legendary large pool player who "Ain't Misbehavin'" in the world of jazz music

(1, 5).clue: Nicknamed "Le Douanier" -- the customs officer -- this self-taught painter's work is seen here

(2, 5).clue: (Judge Hatchett reads the clue.)  A pre-trial device to find out what they've got on you; it's also the name of a space shuttle

(3, 5).clue: Unlike other species of maple, the leaves of this elder have 3 to 7 blades instead of just one

(5, 5).clue: Last name of composer Domenico, son of Alessandro; he wrote over 500 harpsichord pieces

(6, 5).clue: Pen name of short story writer William Sydney Porter, who lived in the woods on the shores of Walden Pond

(0, 0).clue: He won the USA's only boxing gold medal at the 1992 Olympics
